script.speaker: Tyrone
script.text: Xuan, I'm telling you, she's gorgeous -

script.speaker: Xuan
script.text: Not my type, sorry...I mean, I see why you'd think that though. You've always been into that whole athletic vibe.

script.speaker: Tyrone
script.text: Athletic vibe? You make it sound like I'm just attracted to a body type, not the person. That's not fair.

script.speaker: Xuan
script.text: Okay, maybe that was a bad choice of words. I just don't see the attraction, I guess. But to be honest, sometimes I feel like you focus on the surface-level stuff too much. It's like our friends, Rachel and Mike - they're so much more beautiful on the inside, but you barely notice.

script.speaker: Tyrone
script.text: Xuan, come on...I care about them as friends, but that doesn't mean I have to find them attractive. And I do see the inside stuff, you know? I see how beautiful you are inside and out...I mean, that's why I'm with you, right?

script.speaker: Xuan
script.text: I don't know, sometimes I feel like you're just with me because I'm the best you have, not because you truly see me. And honestly, it's been bothering me a lot lately...especially when we're out together and you're checking out other people.

script.speaker: Tyrone
script.text: That's not true...Xuan, you know I love you. And I do see you, I see the beauty in you. Maybe I'm just not as good at expressing it as you are...but I'm trying, okay?

script.speaker: Xuan
script.text: I know you're trying...just try to understand my perspective, okay? For me, it's not just about being attracted to someone, it's about feeling like I'm the only one you see.

script.speaker: Jordan
script.text: I'm telling you, it's really not that bad. You just need to take a few deep breaths and calm down before the presentation.

script.speaker: Tuan
script.text: - but that's easier said than done, when I've got my boss breathing down my neck, asking for those reports. We can't even get a coffee without him mentioning it.

script.speaker: Jordan
script.text: I know, work's been stressing you out lately... Maybe we can grab a drink after this? I heard that new bar downtown has a great selection.

script.speaker: Tuan
script.text: Jordan, you know I'm trying to cut back on drinking. I don't want to be that guy who's always hitting the bar after work. It's just not healthy.

script.speaker: Jordan
script.text: I get it, I'm just trying to help... but you can't let a little stress get to you. When we first met, you told me you were all about living life on the edge, trying new things. I thought that's what I liked about you. Now you're just constantly worried about something.

script.speaker: Tuan
script.text: That was before I had responsibilities, Jordan. Before we started... you know, whatever this is between us. I care about you, but I also care about my job, my future. Can't you understand that?

script.speaker: Jordan
script.text: I do... it's just... sometimes I feel like you're not the same person I fell for. Maybe we just need to take a step back and reevaluate things.

script.speaker: Latoya
script.text: Girl, I don't get why you're so attached to that character arc. It was working fine in the first draft.

script.speaker: Linda
script.text: Working fine? That's exactly the problem - it's been done before. We need to mix it up, give her a different motivation... -

script.speaker: Latoya
script.text: -and you think just changing her backstory is gonna magically fix everything? I don't know, Linda... it feels like we're butchering the whole story.

script.speaker: Linda
script.text: But that's what we do when we're writing - we experiment, try new things. Remember when we first started living together, we said we'd help each other brainstorm, give each other feedback?

script.speaker: Latoya
script.text: Yeah, but that doesn't mean I'm gonna agree with all your wild ideas. Like, what's next? You'll want to change the setting or something?

script.speaker: Linda
script.text: Actually, that's not a bad idea... think about it, Latoya - if we moved the story to a different city, it would give us a whole new set of possibilities...

script.speaker: Latoya
script.text: Linda, stop. Just stop. You're gonna drive me crazy with all these changes. Can't we just stick to the original plan for once?

script.speaker: Miranda
script.text: Rob, can we please talk about the party this weekend? I don't know if I'm up for hosting it here.

script.speaker: Robert
script.text: - I already told people we're having it here, come on Mir.

script.speaker: Miranda
script.text: That's exactly what I'm saying. You already made plans without asking me. As roommates, shouldn't we be on the same page about these things?

script.speaker: Robert
script.text: You know I always try to be considerate, but sometimes social obligations just happen... it's not a big deal. It's not like we're married or something, needing to coordinate every little thing.

script.speaker: Miranda
script.text: Not a big deal? You know our lease has that quiet hours policy, and we have early classes on Monday. I'm trying to respect our living situation here. You're always talking about how you value our friendship, but when it comes to decisions like these, you just do whatever you want.

script.speaker: Robert
script.text: Whoa, calm down. I do value our friendship, that's why I thought you'd be cool with it. And honestly, it's not like I scheduled the party for 3 am. It's just one weekend, Mir.

script.speaker: Miranda
script.text: I'm not trying to be uptight, but it seems like you always assume I'm going to go along with whatever you want. And sometimes that's okay, but other times... I don't know, it feels like you're not respecting our boundaries as roommates.

script.speaker: Robert
script.text: Miranda, I'm sorry... I didn't think about it like that. Can we compromise? We can set an earlier end time for the party, or-.

script.speaker: Cedric
script.text: I had the craziest encounter at the park today, guess who I met?

script.speaker: Elizabeth
script.text: Hmm?

script.speaker: Cedric
script.text: That quirky artist we met at your sister's art show last month -

script.speaker: Elizabeth
script.text: - oh you mean Alex? How is he?

script.speaker: Cedric
script.text: He's doing great! He asked me if I could model for one of his sculptures and I'm thinking of doing it

script.speaker: Elizabeth
script.text: Wait, what? You're gonna pose for his sculpture? Cedric, that's weird

script.speaker: Cedric
script.text: What's weird about it? It'll be fun, and it'll be great to support his art -

script.speaker: Elizabeth
script.text: - no, I mean, will you have to pose nude? Cedric, come on, we've been together three years, and I'm getting a little possessive

script.speaker: Cedric
script.text: Yes, I'll be posing nude, but it's art, not some sleazy photoshoot for a magazine. Alex is a professional, Lizzie

script.speaker: Elizabeth
script.text: I know, I know, but I still don't like the idea... Can we talk about this later? I have a meeting at 10 am tomorrow

script.speaker: Cedric
script.text: Fine, we'll talk about it later. And, by the way, don't be late for our dinner date tomorrow night - you know how long it takes to get a table at that new Italian place we've been wanting to try

script.speaker: Dat
script.text: Hey, can I talk to you for a minute? I noticed you've been staring at me lately, and I'm starting to feel kinda uncomfortable.

script.speaker: Jesus
script.text: What are you talking about, Dat? I wasn't staring at you.

script.speaker: Dat
script.text: Don't play dumb, Jesus. I've seen you watching me from across the yard when I'm mowing the lawn or working in the garden. It's starting to freak me out.

script.speaker: Jesus
script.text: Okay, fine. Maybe I did notice you a little, but it's not what you think. You just always seem so...put together, you know? And I'm just trying to keep up with my yard work. You're always giving me tips and stuff, so I guess I was just admiring your handiwork.

script.speaker: Dat
script.text: Admiring my handiwork? Jesus, come on. I've invited you over for barbecues, and we've talked about our shared fence, but I never thought you felt like that about me.

script.speaker: Jesus
script.text: -I didn't mean it like that, Dat. I swear. Can we just drop it?

script.speaker: Dat
script.text: No, we can't just drop it. You need to understand that it's weirding me out, and I need some space from you right now. We can still be neighbors, but let's just...keep it friendly, okay?

script.speaker: Jesus
script.text: Fine. Sorry, Dat. I didn't mean to make you uncomfortable. I'll back off.

script.speaker: Joseph
script.text: Dude, how's the travel blog coming along? You've been working on it for months now.

script.speaker: Ezequiel
script.text: It's going... Mom's been bugging me to get a 'real job', you know? Like, she doesn't get it. This blog's gonna be huge, I just need to find the right tone...

script.speaker: Joseph
script.text: - Tone? Eze, you've been stuck on that one post about Tokyo for weeks. You're a great writer, but sometimes you just gotta let it go and publish already.

script.speaker: Ezequiel
script.text: Hey, that post's a game-changer! You don't get it, Joe - I'm not just writing for the sake of writing. I'm trying to capture the essence of the city. And, by the way, you're one to talk - remember when you were stuck on that one level in The Legend of Zelda for, like, a year?

script.speaker: Joseph
script.text: That was different, we were kids... Alright, fine. But don't you think you're overthinking this? Sometimes the best stories come from just going with the flow, you know? Like when we backpacked through Europe - we didn't plan every single day, and it was amazing.

script.speaker: Ezequiel
script.text: Yeah, but that was different... We were, like, carefree... Now I've got responsibilities... And, honestly, I'm trying to prove to Mom that I can make a living out of this. That it's not just a 'hobby'... You get it, right?

script.speaker: Joseph
script.text: I get it, bro... I just think you're putting too much pressure on yourself. Maybe take a step back, clear your head... You know, like Dad always says: 'Less thinking, more doing'.

script.speaker: Ezequiel
script.text: Yeah... Yeah, maybe you're right... Ugh, I don't know, Joe... I just feel so stuck sometimes...

script.speaker: Alex
script.text: I don't think you should have invited your mom to stay with us for so long. I mean, we've had her for like a month already, and it's starting to feel like we're running a boarding house...

script.speaker: Hoang
script.text: Come on, she's family -

script.speaker: Alex
script.text: -And I get that, I love her too, but we need some space. You know, just us. Our own space.

script.speaker: Hoang
script.text: Your space? You mean our space, as in, our home we're building together? We should be prioritizing my mom right now because she's been helping out so much with the wedding planning... I know we said no, but she insisted on paying for the catering -

script.speaker: Alex
script.text: Yeah, that was really generous of her, but that's not the point -

script.speaker: Hoang
script.text: And actually that's exactly the point. We should be grateful for her help. And, honestly, it feels like you're just not making an effort to get to know my family better...

script.speaker: Alex
script.text: No, that's not true, I love your family, I just think we need to set some boundaries... Can we at least talk to her about it?

script.speaker: Hoang
script.text: Fine... Yeah, we can talk to her. But let's try to be more understanding, okay? I promise it'll be worth it in the end...

script.speaker: Trinh
script.text: Dad, why can't I have a sleepover on a school night? Everyone else does...

script.speaker: Jalen
script.text: Trinh, we've been over this. School nights are for school, not for staying up late gossiping with your friends. You need your rest.

script.speaker: Trinh
script.text: But it's not just gossiping! We're actually going to study and watch a movie. It'll be fun, and we can help each other with our math homework...

script.speaker: Jalen
script.text: -study? At midnight? I don't think so, kiddo. You're not even good at focusing during the day.

script.speaker: Trinh
script.text: Hey, that's not true! I can focus just fine. And besides, it's not like I'm asking to go to some crazy party or something... just a sleepover at Emma's house.

script.speaker: Jalen
script.text: I know you think you're responsible, but school nights are off-limits, period. Your mom and I agreed on that when you started high school, remember?

script.speaker: Trinh
script.text: Ugh, why do you and mom always have to be so... so... strict?

script.speaker: Jalen
script.text: Trinh, as your parent, it's my job to keep you safe and make sure you're doing what's best for you. And right now, what's best for you is getting a good night's sleep.

script.speaker: Nia
script.text: Dang, have you seen the latest news cycle? They're crucifying that journalist for her reporting on the local mayor's scandal.

script.speaker: Latasha
script.text: Oh, girl, yeah. My mom's been going on and on about it. Thinks she's some kind of hero for speaking truth to power... like, no mom, she's just doing her job.

script.speaker: Nia
script.text: Exactly - and that's the thing, she is doing her job. It's not like she's making this stuff up. I mean, I know we've talked about this before as friends, how we both got into journalism to make a difference... but now I'm starting to think maybe it's all just a facade.

script.speaker: Latasha
script.text: Wait, what? You can't be serious. We've worked too hard to get where we are... I mean, think about our ethics classes, all that stuff about objective reporting... it's not a facade, Nia. You're just having a bad day, that's all.

script.speaker: Nia
script.text: -I am not having a bad day, Tasha. I'm just seeing how easy it is to get torn apart for trying to do the right thing. And honestly, I'm starting to question if it's even worth it...

script.speaker: Latasha
script.text: Nia, stop. You're scaring me. We've been friends since... forever, and I know you're not a quitter. You can't let some bad press get to you like this.

script.speaker: Nia
script.text: Maybe I'm just tired of being disappointed, you know? Tired of seeing the worst in people, even when we're trying to do good. It's exhausting.

script.speaker: Latasha
script.text: I get that. But we can't give up. Not now. We have to keep pushing forward, as friends, as journalists... we owe it to ourselves, and to each other.

script.speaker: John
script.text: Hey, Nam, I wanted to talk to you about what happened at Mark's birthday party the other day -

script.speaker: Nam
script.text: Oh, that. I'm still trying to figure out what even happened...

script.speaker: John
script.text: You said some pretty hurtful things to me, and I felt like you completely misunderstood what I was trying to say... I mean, I remember distinctly saying that I value our friendship above anything, but then you just... stormed off

script.speaker: Nam
script.text: Wait, you think that's what it's about? I thought... never mind. Look, I'm still hurt, John. I felt like you sideswiped me with your comment about 'not being my type' -

script.speaker: John
script.text: No, no, no, I didn't mean it like that - I was just trying to make a joke, and I clearly bombed. I'm really sorry if I hurt you, Nam... Can we please just start over?

script.speaker: Nam
script.text: - No, John, let me finish. I know you don't mean to, but sometimes your jokes can be... insensitive. I've been feeling like we've grown apart lately, and I'm not sure I know where I stand with you anymore...

script.speaker: John
script.text: Whoa, hold up - grown apart? What's going on? I thought we were... I thought we were doing great, actually. Better than great... We've been hanging out all the time, going on dates -

script.speaker: Nam
script.text: Exactly - dates. We're supposedly courting, but I still don't know where I stand with you... Are you even interested in taking things to the next level?

script.speaker: John
script.text: Of course I am, Nam... I care about you deeply. I just didn't realize you felt this way... Can we try to, uh, figure this out together? Please?

script.speaker: Patricia
script.text: Thu, I really don't think you should be focusing on your art career right now. You're not married, you're still living with me, and your financial independence is practically zero...

script.speaker: Thu
script.text: Mom, I'm trying. I have a small income from my freelance work... it's not a lot, but it's a start

script.speaker: Patricia
script.text: - Fre- - that's not enough, Thu. And it's not just about the money. What about your future plans? Do you have any idea what you want to do in the next five years?

script.speaker: Thu
script.text: Mom, I know you're worried, but I'm trying to figure things out. And I'm actually thinking about going back to school for graphic design... maybe next year

script.speaker: Patricia
script.text: School? You just dropped out of college! How can I trust that you'll be able to finish this time? And what about your student loans?

script.speaker: Thu
script.text: That was a different major, okay? And I've been thinking about it a lot... I'll take out another loan if I have to. I really think this is what I want to do. Can't you just support me for once?

script.speaker: Patricia
script.text: Support you? I've been supporting you your whole life, Thu. But as your parent, it's my job to make sure you're making responsible decisions. And right now, I'm not convinced that you are...

script.speaker: Olivia
script.text: Dude, I need you to revise this translation - it's way off. Mom always said we were the ones who got Dad's language skills, but I'm starting to think that's just a myth.

script.speaker: Carlos
script.text: - Hold up, Liv, I'm busy with the Smith account. Can't it wait?

script.speaker: Olivia
script.text: No, it can't wait. This client needs it by tonight and our boss already chewed me out this morning about the missed deadline. Translation challenges aren't exactly new to us, are they?

script.speaker: Carlos
script.text: What's the big deal? We work at a translation firm, it's not like they're going to fire us. And by the way, I'm your brother, not your personal translator.

script.speaker: Olivia
script.text: My personal translator? You're on the same team as me, Carlos. Communication is key here - remember when we used to help Mom and Dad with their business calls?

script.speaker: Carlos
script.text: Yeah, yeah, I remember. Fine. Give me the file.

script.speaker: Olivia
script.text: I sent it to you 20 minutes ago. Check your email.

script.speaker: Carlos
script.text: Ugh... Okay, I'll look at it. But make it quick, I have a meeting with the team in 30 minutes.

script.speaker: Olivia
script.text: You owe me one, Carlos. We're siblings, not coworkers... though right now, I'm not sure which one is more annoying.

script.speaker: Ebony
script.text: I don't know, John, I just can't seem to find the inspiration to write these days -

script.speaker: John
script.text: - maybe that's because you're putting too much pressure on yourself. You've been saying that for weeks, and honestly, it's getting a bit frustrating...

script.speaker: Ebony
script.text: Frustrating for you? You're not the one who's trying to meet a deadline. Sometimes I feel like you're just not supportive of my creative endeavors...

script.speaker: John
script.text: That's not fair, Ebony. I'm always here for you, and I've been very supportive. You're just really stressed lately, and it's rubbing off on me. I'm trying to be patient, but it's not easy when you're snapping at me all the time...

script.speaker: Ebony
script.text: I'm sorry if I've been snapping at you... It's just, when I'm in the middle of a project, I get so consumed by it, and sometimes I forget about everything else... Our anniversary is coming up, right? What were we going to do to celebrate?

script.speaker: John
script.text: Um, I don't know... You've been so caught up in your writing, I figured we'd just do something low-key this year. Maybe just have a quiet dinner at home... But can we please focus on your writing issues for now?

script.speaker: Ebony
script.text: No, no, it's fine. I don't want to talk about it anymore. I'm just going to go for a walk and clear my head...

script.speaker: John
script.text: Ebony, wait -

script.speaker: Cedric
script.text: Seriously, Dad? You're grounding me for a month just because I missed my curfew by an hour? That's so unfair...

script.speaker: Lazaro
script.text: Unfair? You think that's unfair? You're 17 years old, and you're still not taking responsibility for your actions. I'm your parent, it's my job to teach you -

script.speaker: Cedric
script.text: But, I know you're just doing this because Mom's been on your case about me. You're just trying to prove a point to her...

script.speaker: Lazaro
script.text: That's not true, Cedric. And even if it was, that's not the point. The point is you broke the rules, and now you have to face the consequences. You need to learn -

script.speaker: Cedric
script.text: - learn what, Dad? That you get to control every aspect of my life? Newsflash, Dad, I'm almost an adult. I can make my own decisions...

script.speaker: Lazaro
script.text: Not as long as you're living under my roof, you can't. And another thing, what's with the attitude? You're not some kind of victim here, Cedric. You made a choice, and now you have to deal with it...

script.speaker: Susan
script.text: Sofia I've been looking everywhere for my favorite coffee mug -

script.speaker: Sofia
script.text: Oh yeah I think I remember I borrowed it a while back - I'm pretty sure it's in my room somewhere

script.speaker: Susan
script.text: A while back? I haven't seen it in months - can you please just put it back in the cabinet where you found it?

script.speaker: Sofia
script.text: - I will, I will just... I'll get to it eventually okay?

script.speaker: Susan
script.text: Eventually? Sofia, it's been months - that's just not considerate as a roommate. We're supposed to be respectful of each other's stuff. Remember when we said we'd return each other's things as soon as we're done?

script.speaker: Sofia
script.text: I remember, but it slipped my mind, and then... I dunno it just got buried under all my other stuff

script.speaker: Susan
script.text: Look, just make a conscious effort to put things back where you found them, okay? And also maybe just tidy up your room so it's easier to find things when I need to borrow something from you

script.speaker: Sofia
script.text: Fine, sorry... it won't happen again

script.speaker: Wei
script.text: Mom, why are you being so serious today?

script.speaker: Ngoc
script.text: - Wei, this isn't something to joke about. You got into that graduate program, and I'm trying to be supportive. I just think it's a big commitment.

script.speaker: Wei
script.text: That's exactly what I mean, Mom. You're supposed to be happy and congratulating me, not lecturing me about the difficulties.

script.speaker: Ngoc
script.text: I am happy for you, but someone has to think about the reality of the situation. And as your mother, it's my job to consider what's best for you. You're going to have to be more responsible now.

script.speaker: Wei
script.text: I know that, Mom. And I appreciate it. But sometimes I just need you to be my friend, you know? Not just my parent all the time. Can't you just be happy and celebrate with me for once?

script.speaker: Ngoc
script.text: Wei, I... Fine. Congratulations on getting into the program. I know how hard you worked for it. I'm proud of you.

script.speaker: Wei
script.text: See? That wasn't so hard, was it?

script.speaker: Ngoc
script.text: No, it wasn't. Now, let's talk about the logistics...

script.speaker: Nia
script.text: I saw your new profile picture on social media, Hang. You look so different. I love the new haircut.

script.speaker: Hang
script.text: Thanks... I was thinking of trying something new. Although, mom was a bit shocked when she saw it.

script.speaker: Nia
script.text: Yeah, mom can be a bit dramatic sometimes. But honestly, I'm more curious about why you decided to change your look now.

script.speaker: Hang
script.text: Just wanted to try something different, I guess. You know, people have been saying I look too childish with my old hairstyle- it's pretty annoying.

script.speaker: Nia
script.text: Annoying? Who said that? Was it those new friends you hang out with?

script.speaker: Hang
script.text: -No, no, it's not them. I don't know, people in general. And don't make a big deal out of it, Nia.

script.speaker: Nia
script.text: I'm not making a big deal out of it! I just want to know. This is coming from your concerned sister, you know?

script.speaker: Hang
script.text: Concerned? You're just curious. And besides, I can handle my own life. Remember when you decided to dye your hair blue senior year? Dad freaked out.

script.speaker: Nia
script.text: That was different. I was in high school, and it was just a phase. You're... I don't know, this is just so sudden.

script.speaker: Hang
script.text: You know what? Forget it. I don't even know why I'm discussing this with you.

script.speaker: Tanisha
script.text: Jalen, mom's been on my case about inviting you to Karen's engagement party, she said you haven't been to any family gatherings recently

script.speaker: Jalen
script.text: Yeah, I know. She knows I'm busy with work and stuff. Plus, Karen's not really my friend, we just grew up together

script.speaker: Tanisha
script.text: Oh, come on, it's not like you're asking for a huge commitment. You'd only need to be there for a few hours, and mom would really appreciate it

script.speaker: Jalen
script.text: - Mom would appreciate it? You know mom's just trying to get the whole family together to discuss the will... again

script.speaker: Tanisha
script.text: That's not the point. Anyway, what about Karen? We used to hang out all the time when we were kids

script.speaker: Jalen
script.text: I know, but we both have our own lives now. And honestly, Karen's changed a lot since high school

script.speaker: Tanisha
script.text: Changed? How? You used to always have a crush on her

script.speaker: Jalen
script.text: Don't remind me... Look, just tell mom I said hi and I'll try to make it, okay?

script.speaker: Hang
script.text: Dad, come on, you're so unfair -

script.speaker: David
script.text: Hang, I'm trying to talk to you about this. You've been spending a lot of time with this new friend from school... Chris, was it?

script.speaker: Hang
script.text: Yeah, that's him. And? You're always saying I should be more sociable, right?

script.speaker: David
script.text: I am. But I saw how he was looking at you, and I don't think it's a good idea for you to be alone with him. You're only 16, Hang.

script.speaker: Hang
script.text: What's that supposed to mean? You think Chris is interested in me or something? That's so ridiculous... He's just a friend.

script.speaker: David
script.text: I'm trying to protect you, Hang. I know you think you're old enough to take care of yourself, but trust me, I've seen how boys can be at that age.

script.speaker: Hang
script.text: Ugh, Dad... you're so embarrassing... And you have no right to decide who I can and can't hang out with. I'm practically an adult.

script.speaker: David
script.text: As your parent, I do have the right, Hang. And I'm not going to let you just go off with some boy who -

script.speaker: Hang
script.text: -has a crush on me? Oh my god, Dad, you're projecting or something... Chris doesn't even feel that way about me.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Even so, I don't want you to be alone with him, okay? Your curfew is still 10, and I expect you to stick to it.

script.speaker: Darius
script.text: I'm kinda surprised you're still wearing those bright pink hair clips, Thuy. I mean, I've seen you wearing them for like, weeks now.

script.speaker: Thuy
script.text: So? I like them. What's the big deal?

script.speaker: Darius
script.text: No big deal, really... I'm just worried people might get the wrong idea. Like, we had that one party last week and-

script.speaker: Thuy
script.text: -oh, stop. Don't start with that again, Darius. You know I'm not trying to attract any unwanted attention. I just like the clips.

script.speaker: Darius
script.text: I get that, but you're always talking about how you hate it when people stare at you, and then you go and do something that, you know, makes them stare...

script.speaker: Thuy
script.text: Darius, honestly, sometimes I wonder if you even listen to me. I hate it when people stare because of my clothes or the way I look, not because of my hair clips. There's a difference. And by the way, I think it's kinda cool that our landlord said we could paint the living room, don't you?

script.speaker: Darius
script.text: Uh, yeah, the painting thing... sure, that's great, I guess. Anyway, I still don't get why you insist on wearing those clips. You know I've been meaning to ask, can I try them out sometime?

script.speaker: Thuy
script.text: -no way, Darius. Don't even think about it.

script.speaker: Darius
script.text: What, why not? Curious, that's all... I wonder if I'd be able to pull them off.

script.speaker: Linda
script.text: So, I was thinking, we've been seeing each other for a while now, maybe we could start talking about our future plans?

script.speaker: William
script.text: Future plans? Like, marriage and stuff?

script.speaker: Linda
script.text: Well, yeah, maybe eventually. But also, like, do we want to move in together, or-

script.speaker: William
script.text: - Hold on, Linda, let's not get ahead of ourselves, okay? I've just started my own business, and I need to focus on that for now.

script.speaker: Linda
script.text: That's exactly what I'm saying - we need to be on the same page financially if we want to make this work. I mean, I've got my own savings, but I'm not sure if I'm ready to be tied down to someone else's debt.

script.speaker: William
script.text: My debt? You're not even considering how much I'm investing in this business. It's going to pay off in the long run, I'm sure of it.

script.speaker: Linda
script.text: I am considering it, and that's why I'm worried. What if it doesn't work out? What if we're stuck with all this debt and no way to pay it off? And what about our future, like I was saying - do you even want to get married, or have kids, or-

script.speaker: William
script.text: - Whoa, slow down, okay? Let's just focus on one thing at a time. Can't we just enjoy our time together without all these expectations?

script.speaker: Deandre
script.text: Honey, I need to ask you something, I- I don't know if you're aware, but there's been some rumors going around at the office about you and our coworker, Alex.

script.speaker: Mary
script.text: -What rumors? What are you talking about, Deandre?

script.speaker: Deandre
script.text: I don't know, people are saying that you and Alex are, you know... close. Like, too close. And I don't want any of this to affect our professional relationships or, you know, our reputation at work.

script.speaker: Mary
script.text: Close? Deandre, we're working on the same project, that's all. We collaborate sometimes. You know how it is when you're working on a team. Why are you bringing this up all of a sudden?

script.speaker: Deandre
script.text: Because, well, I heard it from my friend, Jake, and he said it's been going around for a while. And I don't know, maybe I'm just being paranoid, but it's just that we have our home, our bills to pay... everything to consider, and I don't want any drama or problems at work.

script.speaker: Mary
script.text: Deandre, stop. You need to clarify things before you start jumping to conclusions. I'm telling you, there's nothing going on. Alex and I are just colleagues. You know how much I value our relationship and our life together. Why would I do something to jeopardize that?

script.speaker: Deandre
script.text: I'm sorry, I just... I don't know, I guess I just wasn't sure what to think. And I know I should've just talked to you about it first instead of listening to rumors...

script.speaker: Mary
script.text: Exactly. You should've talked to me. But it's okay, I know you're just looking out for us. Let's just forget about it and focus on our life together, okay?

script.speaker: Darius
script.text: Carlos, I'm getting frustrated with your recent performance at the newspaper. It seems like you're not putting in the effort you used to.

script.speaker: Carlos
script.text: Effort? You think I'm not putting in effort? -

script.speaker: Darius
script.text: -No, no, let me finish. Your mother and I have always encouraged you to pursue your passion for journalism, but these recent articles... they lack substance.

script.speaker: Carlos
script.text: That's not true. I've been working hard to get scoops, but no one wants to read about the real issues anymore. Everyone just wants clickbait headlines.

script.speaker: Darius
script.text: I understand that, but as a journalist, it's your job to pursue the truth, not just what's popular. And besides, you're not even fact-checking properly anymore... I saw the article you wrote last week, and it was riddled with errors.

script.speaker: Carlos
script.text: You're always on my case about something, Dad. You know I'm trying my best. Can't you just support me for once?

script.speaker: Darius
script.text: Carlos, I am supporting you. That's why I'm pushing you to do better. As your parent, it's my job to make sure you live up to your potential... and right now, you're not even close.

script.speaker: Carlos
script.text: Whatever, Dad...

script.speaker: Luis
script.text: Hey Jordan, can I talk to you for a sec?

script.speaker: Jordan
script.text: What's up?

script.speaker: Luis
script.text: It's about your yard. I mean, I know it's not my business, but it's starting to get a little wild, and it's affecting my property value. And honestly, it's been like this for months. I've tried to mention it to you before...

script.speaker: Jordan
script.text: Whoa, hold up, this again? Listen, Luis, I hear you, but I've got a lot going on right now. My mom's been in and out of the hospital, and I just can't deal with this right now.

script.speaker: Luis
script.text: I understand that, and I'm sorry to hear about your mom, but this is our neighborhood's association, and we have rules. If your yard looks like this, it's gonna affect everyone's property value, not just mine. Plus, the HOA's been complaining... and... well, I just think it'd be better if you could clean it up a bit, maybe hire someone to do it for you, I don't know...

script.speaker: Jordan
script.text: Look, Luis, I appreciate your concern and all, but can we talk about this some other time? I promise I'll get to it eventually, just not now.

script.speaker: Luis
script.text: Eventually's not really helpful here. I'm trying to be considerate of your situation, but there's got to be some understanding from your side too, you know? It's not just about you; it's about our whole neighborhood. Can we at least schedule a time to talk about this later?

script.speaker: Jordan
script.text: Fine, yeah, sure. How about next week sometime? I should be free by then.

script.speaker: Luis
script.text: That sounds good. Next week, let's say, Wednesday? We can discuss this further then.

script.speaker: Jordan
script.text: Sounds good.

script.speaker: Latonya
script.text: Quang, seriously? I don't think mom or dad would be happy if they saw how little you've contributed to our business. I'm doing all the work here.

script.speaker: Quang
script.text: - Hold on, Latonya, that's not true. I've been bringing in clients and doing the finances.

script.speaker: Latonya
script.text: Finances? You call juggling our accounts 'doing finances'? I'm the one who handles the actual business side of things. You just play around with numbers all day.

script.speaker: Quang
script.text: I'm doing my part, Latonya. And by the way, those 'numbers' are what keep our business running. You can't just focus on the creative side and expect everything else to fall into place.

script.speaker: Latonya
script.text: I'm not just talking about the creative side, Quang. I'm talking about our business strategy, our marketing plans... all the things that actually bring in money. You need to step up your game if you want to be a real partner in this business.

script.speaker: Quang
script.text: Fine, maybe I haven't been as involved as you, but you can't just dictate how I should be contributing. We're siblings, Latonya. We're supposed to work together, not have you bossing me around all the time.

script.speaker: Latonya
script.text: I'm not bossing you around, Quang. I just want us to be on the same page. Remember when we were kids and mom would always say 'teamwork makes the dream work'? We need to start working like a team again.

script.speaker: Quang
script.text: Yeah, I remember. But we're not kids anymore, Latonya. We need to find a better way to work together, one that doesn't involve you constantly criticizing me.

script.speaker: Latonya
script.text: I... I just want what's best for our business, Quang. And for us, as siblings.

script.speaker: Tyrone
script.text: Mom, I need to talk to you about this article I'm working on for school. It's about the Smith's divorce and I found out some stuff from my friend who's their kid's babysitter

script.speaker: Hanh
script.text: Tyrone, we don't gossip about other people's problems, especially in a small town like this. You know how it is, it spreads like wildfire. And what's this about the babysitter?

script.speaker: Tyrone
script.text: Well, it's not exactly gossip - I'm writing about how the local paper handled it. They published all these private details and it's got me wondering if that's okay from a journalistic standpoint. Do they have a right to share that stuff?

script.speaker: Hanh
script.text: I understand where you're coming from, but-

script.speaker: Tyrone
script.text: -No, mom, listen. It's not just about the Smiths, it's about our family too. What if something like that happened to us? Would you want our business all over the front page?

script.speaker: Hanh
script.text: Tyrone, we're not going to have a family scandal. And even if we did, I'd rather not have you drawing attention to it through some article. Your father's always been a bit... private, you know that

script.speaker: Tyrone
script.text: Private? That's exactly my point! He's always telling me to respect people's boundaries, but what about when it's a 'public interest' thing? Where do we draw the line?

script.speaker: Hanh
script.text: We'll talk about this later, okay? I have to go pick up your sister from practice. And Tyrone, please be careful with this article, I don't want you to stir up trouble

script.speaker: Huong
script.text: I saw you writing away at your kitchen table last night, Jordan. Researching another piece for the news?

script.speaker: Jordan
script.text: Just working on a story, yeah. Can't reveal too much yet, though.

script.speaker: Huong
script.text: Fair enough. I've been meaning to ask, have you heard anything about the Johnson's divorce?

script.speaker: Jordan
script.text: Uh, actually, I - Huong, I'm not sure I'm comfortable talking about that right now.

script.speaker: Huong
script.text: What's wrong? Oh, come on, you're a journalist - you can't just pick and choose what gossip to spread around.

script.speaker: Jordan
script.text: - I'm not gossiping, Huong. There's a difference between reporting news and sharing family secrets. And even if I did know something, I wouldn't share it. That's not ethical journalism.

script.speaker: Huong
script.text: Ethics, schmethics. You're just being too sensitive, Jordan. Besides, you're not going to get the scoop if you're not willing to dig a little dirt.

script.speaker: Jordan
script.text: I understand where you're coming from, but as a journalist and as your neighbor, I value our relationship and the people in this community. I'm not going to compromise that for the sake of a story.

script.speaker: Taylor
script.text: I'm telling you, Yadira, I had a huge crush on him back in high school. I mean, who wouldn't?

script.speaker: Yadira
script.text: - No way, he was so awkward, always tripping over his own feet... that's not attractive

script.speaker: Taylor
script.text: Aww, come on, that's part of his charm. And have you seen those dreamy eyes of his?

script.speaker: Yadira
script.text: Dreamy eyes? You're such a romantic. As friends, I thought we'd have more realistic standards, Taylor

script.speaker: Taylor
script.text: I am being realistic â€“ we're not talking about a relationship here. I just think he's really cute and I had a major crush on him back then...

script.speaker: Yadira
script.text: And I think you're biased because you've got that nostalgia going on. I mean, we were all weird-looking in high school. Beauty's just relative, Taylor

script.speaker: Taylor
script.text: But that's not the point. The point is, we've changed, and I think he's grown into his features, and I still find him attractive... objectively, I mean

script.speaker: Yadira
script.text: Objectively? Ha! There's nothing objective about attraction, it's all personal taste. I just don't see what you see in him, that's all

script.speaker: Darius
script.text: Mom, I'm telling you, they're trying to silence me at work. I have sources saying the company's involved in some shady dealings, but my boss won't let me run the story.

script.speaker: Emma
script.text: Darius, honey, I understand why you're passionate about this, but sometimes as a journalist, you have to know when to pick your battles. Your father and I always taught you to be committed to your job, not just the parts that excite you.

script.speaker: Darius
script.text: -That's not fair, mom. You're always saying I should stand up for what I believe in. This is exactly what that means. And it's not just about the job, it's about the public's right to know what's going on.

script.speaker: Emma
script.text: I'm not saying you shouldn't stand up for yourself... I just think you need to consider the bigger picture here. What's more important, getting the story out there, or keeping your job and being able to take care of yourself?

script.speaker: Darius
script.text: That's the problem, mom. The workplace dynamics are all wrong. Everyone's more concerned with keeping their heads down and getting a promotion than actually doing real journalism. I don't want to be a part of that...

script.speaker: Emma
script.text: Darius, as your parent, it's my job to worry about your well-being. And right now, I'm worried that you're letting your passion cloud your judgment. Why don't we talk about this some more when your father gets home?
